etymologies: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French warantie, variant of garantie (see guaranty). Early use was as a legal term denoting a covenant annexed to a conveyance of property, in which the vender affirmed the security of the title

definitions: a written guarantee, issued to the purchaser of an article by its manufacturer, promising to repair or replace it if necessary within a specified period of time

examples.text: the car comes with a three-year warranty
as your machine is under warranty, I suggest getting it checked

shortDefinitions: written guarantee, issued to purchaser of article by its manufacturer, promising to repair or replace it if necessary within specified period of time

definitions: (in contract law) a promise that something in furtherance of the contract is guaranteed by one of the contractors, especially the seller's promise that the thing being sold is as promised or represented.
shortDefinitions: promise that something in furtherance of contract is guaranteed by one of contractors

definitions: (in an insurance contract) an engagement by the insured party that certain statements are true or that certain conditions shall be fulfilled, the breach of it invalidating the policy.
shortDefinitions: (in insurance contract) engagement by insured party that certain statements are true or that certain conditions shall be fulfilled

definitions: (in property law) a covenant by which the seller binds themselves and their heirs to secure to the buyer the estate conveyed in the deed.
shortDefinitions: covenant by which seller binds themselves and their heirs to secure to buyer estate conveyed in deed

definitions: (in contract law) a term or promise in a contract, breach of which entitles the innocent party to damages but not to treat the contract as discharged by breach.
shortDefinitions: term or promise in contract, breach

definitions: justification or grounds for an action or belief

examples.text: you have no warranty for such an audacious doctrine

shortDefinitions: justification or grounds for action or belief
